title: Lady Of Deceit
opening: In order to secure a successful invasion of Fhirdiad, Edelgard launches a raid on the Fortress City of Arianrhod, which occupies a key position on the border. At Arianrhod, a mage serving House Blaiddyd named Cornelia and the head of House Fraldarius, Rodrigue, strengthen their defenses.
With razor-sharp focus on the unification of Fódlan, Edelgard feigns a premature assault on Fhirdiad while the Black Eagle Strike Force instead descends on the southern stronghold of Arianrhod.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: The time has come to invade the Kingdom capital. Or so I declared. In truth, we'll be advancing to a different location. Only you and the rest of the Black Eagle Strike Force can know. Please bear that in mind.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: Seems you've already anticipated our intentions, Professor. Well done. Before Fhirdiad, we must take Arianrhod, which lies near the border between the Empire and the Kingdom. As a city on the boundary of the two territories, it must be taken at once.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: There is another location we must take before moving on to Fhirdiad. South of the capital, there is a fortress city on the border of the Empire and the Kingdom. It is called Arianrhod, and we must take control of it at once.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: There are many mages within Arianrhod. We will also face Cornelia, a general of the Kingdom. We must also contend with Rodrigue, the head of House Fraldarius, as well as his troops. Once we defeat them, Arianrhod will be ours.

dialogue.speaker: Hubert
dialogue.line: I hear Cornelia has a suspicious magic weapon at her disposal. We must attack before the enemy can respond with defensive measures. That is why we are preparing an assault before even our allies are aware. Even within our ranks, there is no way to know with certainty that there is not a rat among us who would leak such information.

dialogue.speaker: Edelgard
dialogue.line: When Arianrhod falls, we'll focus on striking Fhirdiad from both the south and the east. The deeper we carve our way into Kingdom and church territory, the more favorable our position. As ever, I'm counting on you, my teacher.

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Professor? Halt! Don't come in here!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Hasn't this happened before?

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Ugh, I thought I told you to forget about that. There's something I don't want you to see.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Is it a portrait?

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: So...you know about it. Yes, it's a portrait. Of you. I painted it myself. It's, uh...quite disgraceful. I did a terrible job with it, and it looks nothing like you.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Thank you for that, Edelgard.

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: I'm happy that you appreciate my efforts, but...please don't touch that door.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: This was a trying month, but we did manage to hold Garreg Mach—if only just. The power of Seteth and Flayn was certainly a sight to behold. The archbishop's supporters were strong. But with this victory, we have all but cornered the Church of Seiros and its knights. The goddess above shall give away to the darkness that has long dwelled below...

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: This was a trying month, but we did manage to hold Garreg Mach—if only just. Honestly, I did not expect such strident supporters of the archbishop as Seteth and Flayn to flee. But with this victory, we have all but cornered the Church of Seiros and its knights. The goddess above shall give away to the darkness that has long dwelled below...

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Dimitri, the King of Faerghus. He despises Edelgard and everything she stands for. I am of the opinion that a man seized by such strong feelings is not fit to be king. It is a sad situation, really.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Kings are people too.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: If he cannot suppress his emotions to make reasoned decisions, he should abdicate.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Kings can't be emotional?

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: No, they cannot. Kingly judgement has to be wholly separate from the emotions of the individual.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: At any rate, I find it hard to believe that Dimitri could defeat Edelgard.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: There are stories of Heroes' Relics a thousand years ago of which we have no real evidence today. So many, in fact, that I'm led to wonder if those Relics are nothing more than legends... Especially since we know of Relics like those passed down in the families of the 10 Fódlan Elites.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: All right! Off to the Kingdom's capital we go! What's the matter? Should I not be excited? I can't help it. Everyone's gotta have something to look forward to!

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: I've got a dream, you know. Not that I think it'll come true, but it's nice to hope. I'd like to get out of Fódlan and travel across the sea. Maybe to Dagda. Maybe even past that. I want to see all the wild jungles out there, the huge flowers, and--oh--the carnivorous plants! I know it's not realistic, and I know it's probably impossible, but that's what I'd like.

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: I've got a dream, you know. I don't know if it'll come true, but it's nice to hope. Remember when I went to Brigid, with Petra? I drew a picture of some of the flowers I saw there. Next time, I wanna go even farther. Maybe Dagda. Maybe even past that. I wanna fill a whole book with the drawings of the biggest plants I see! And the carnivorous ones especially! Oh, I hope I get the chance...

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: I heard that Randolph died in battle guarding Garreg Mach. We knew each other for, wow, more than five years... My chest feels tight. Think about it. There's no end in sight to the fighting. I might be next. Any of us could be.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We'll make it through together. Relationship with Dorothea goes up)

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: Together, eh? That sounds like one of Sylvain's old pick-up lines! But yes, let's get through this war. Together.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I don't see an end to it either.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: When the days are filled with fighting, or preparing to fight, it really does feel like this could last forever.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: I have excitement in my heart for secret tactics! I enjoy attacks that are surprising.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Why's that?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Because it's like hunting?

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Yes. Hunting is like doing surprise attacks on prey.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Surprise attacks are safe with friends. Fewer injuries. That is a wonderful thing. I have no liking for the thought of losing someone.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Since I allied with you and the emperor, my resolve has never wavered. I abandoned my country. I am prepared to kill my father, and kill a man I once called my friend. Resolute as I am, my sword feels...heavy.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: In Faerghus, there's an amazing knight of House Rowe they call the Gray Lion. I heard about him from Lonato, who was an acquaintance of his. Apparently he's getting old, but with each year that passes, he only hones his skills even more.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Some people are so in awe of King Dimitri, they call him the Tempest King. After he wins, there won't be anything left. He'll be a storm, leaving nothing behind. He hates the Empire so much he's willing to do anything to bring it down.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: He hates the Empire?

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Yeah, because of the role the Empire played in the Tragedy of Duscur. You know, even back at the Officers Academy, he never had much to do with anyone from the Empire.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: He wasn't like that before?

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: No. Then again, maybe we just didn't actually know him at all.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: We'll be fighting Dimitri and his troops soon. We all oughta train a little harder if we want to stay alive.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Well, that was certainly frightening.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: What was?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: The church?

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: You're very perceptive, Professor.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Having to fight against the Church of Seiros was unnerving. To push back against something I've hinged so much of my life upon... I was terrified. But now we must fight Lady Rhea, and I won't back down!

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: I used to live in the Kingdom capital with my parents. I know we've got no choice but to fight the Kingdom, but I really don't want Fhirdiad to become a battlefield... Lots of my old friends still live in the city, and many people there were kind to me. If fighting breaks out there, all of those people might get caught up in it...

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: I never thought this day would come--that I'd fight my homeland. My betrothed was a knight who served the king. He died bravely to protect the future of our country. Now I'm betraying the place he fought to protect. I'm betraying him. But I must do this. Professor. I believe in the path you have chosen for us.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: It seems we will soon set foot in Fhirdiad. I used to live there, you know. Though that was before my time in the Officers Academy.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Were you a hostage?

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: No, of course not. There is a school of magic there, which I was enrolled in for a time.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Were you an exchange student?

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: That's right. I was enrolled at the school of magic there for a time.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: Trouble within the Kingdom forced me to return to Alliance lands. There was much I had yet to learn.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Hyah! Next up is the Kingdom's capital! We're coming for you! What's wrong? Was that too much? Maybe it was too dramatic...or I didn't yell it loud enough!

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Soon we'll assault Fhirdiad, the Kingdom's capital! This'll be one for the history books. Our enemy won't hold anything back. I'm quivering with excitement at the very thought of it!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Bravo. You put on a good show.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Heh, I appreciate the compliment! I worried I was laying it on too thick...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Your performance is a bit stilted.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Is it? I thought I sounded quite sincere.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: In any case, let's do our best! We're coming for you, Fhirdiad! And so on, heh.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: I've been informed of the surprise attack. That information could be devastating, were the enemy to find out. It moves me to know I've been trusted with it. Edelgard and those within the army... They really do trust me. Initially, I had my own motives for joining the Black Eagle Strike Force. But now, all I want is to support Edelgard.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: Even though we're denying the doctrine and fighting the knights, I keep praying to the goddess... When I think about those who have fallen in battle... I...I have no choice but to pray. The goddess of the church may be a fallacy, but I'm sure she still exists in some form. I'm weak. I would be nothing without her.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Don't you think this plan to use the entire army for a surprise attack is a bit--I don't know--cowardly? Sorry, the word just kind of slipped out. Maybe don't tell Edelgard or Hubert I said that. No matter the target or strategy, I'll do my job.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: It's hard to feel cheery when you've just gone to battle against old friends. Mraaaugh! No! I will not let myself be gloomy!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Go easy on yourself.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: You're trying to take care of me, but it's supposed to be the other way around! Forgive me, Jeralt!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: How about you go fishing?

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: Fishing, huh? That may brighten my mood a bit, now that you mention it.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: I'm sure it must be even harder for you, to fight against your students. When times are tough, just remember, you can always rely on your old pal Alois!

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Last month's fight with the Knights of Seiros was a disaster.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Are you all right?

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Are you asking me if I'm OK with killing my former colleagues?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You seem fine.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: I am. I never believed in Seiros. And my old colleagues are now just enemies.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Sometimes it's easier to get by without any personal attachment or religious beliefs.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: There's a school of sorcery in Fhirdiad, which is staffed by the top minds of magical research. The study of Crests and sorcery should not be separate. I've often thought I should pay them a visit someday. I never imagined I might end up invading the place with an army though. Not how I imagined it at all.

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: How have we come to this? Fighting the archbishop and her knights... I'd never imagined... I hate this. So much. Professor, I tried. I gave treatment to everyone I could, but...but lives were still lost. The infirmary is as much a morgue right now as it is a place of care and healing...

conversation.speaker: Jeritza
conversation.line: The Knights of Seiros... They certainly know how to inflict pain. However. The demon within me will be satiated only by fighting you.

conversation.speaker: Anna
conversation.line: There's unrest everywhere these days. All of my fellow merchants seem to be endangered. I hope things go back to normal soon. People need more to smile about, aside from my great deals.

conversation.speaker: Fleche
conversation.line: My brother fought proudly to the end and died an honorable death. He said something to me before the battle. That he was entrusting his dream to me... I'm gonna see this battle through to the end. I'm gonna fight for my brother!

conversation.speaker: Gatekeeper
conversation.line: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Between Garreg Mach and Fhirdiad stretch the plains of Tailtean. That's the sight of the ancient battle where Nemesis, the King of Liberation, fought the prophet Seiros. If our forces end up fighting our enemies there... It'll be a clash passed down through the ages!

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: Cornelia! I have a report from our scouts. The Imperial army that departed from Garreg Mach en route to the capital now appears to be marching here.

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: The speed of the army's movement quickens... They will be here to invade within days. I just sent some of my troops to support the capital. It is likely to be a fierce fight...

intro.speaker: Cornelia
intro.line: How could this be? I have not heard a thing about... Ah... I understand now. I am the target.

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: You? Are you sure they do not mean to take Arianrhod for strategic reasons?

intro.speaker: Cornelia
intro.line: It would appear so from the outside. However, the circumstances are not that simple. And will you calm yourself? It will not be a fierce fight whatsoever. The sweet children I have prepared will protect Arianrhod well...

intro.speaker: Hubert
intro.line: Arianhrod is a fortress city that was built about 400 years ago. Originally a base on the front lines of the battle against the Kingdom, it was built using Imperial money and technology.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: However, the head of House Rowe secretly planned to betray the Empire. As the fortress neared completion, it was rebuilt as a base to defend against the Empire. When the fortress was completed, House Rowe declared its vassalage to the Kingdom.

intro.speaker: Hubert
intro.line: Since then, Arianrhod has never fallen. Not once. The beautiful white walls that protect it against its enemies have earned it the nickname the Silver Maiden. In the end, that is all it is to the Empire... the Silver Maiden stands as a bitter memory.

intro.speaker: Petra
intro.line: We will now be destroying that memory. The past is the past. Now is now.

intro.speaker: Caspar
intro.line: A fortress that has never fallen?! Ooh, I can't wait to make it fall!

intro.speaker: Ferdinand
intro.line: How savage of you. And yet, I must say I agree with the sentiment. Let us take the sturdy Arianrhod and continue our march against the Kingdom!

intro.speaker: Linhardt
intro.line: Unfortunately, it will soon no longer be invincible. The Silver Maiden's iron skin is about to be damaged. It's sad, really.

intro.speaker: Petra
intro.line: Is it silver or iron? Use your language with clarity, please.

intro.speaker: Dorothea
intro.line: Really, Lin. There must be a better way to say that. Since we are attacking a heavily guarded place, we must take extra care to prevent allies from getting injured.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: Thank you, everyone. I'm counting on all of you. Now, let's resume our advance.

intro.speaker: Hubert
intro.line: This battle is for the future of Fódlan...

battle.speaker: Cornelia
battle.line: How could they deceive me and close in on Arianrhod?! But it's not like I'm just going to just stand by and watch... I will slaughter them all.

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: So this is the Silver Maiden... Seeing it with my own eyes, I finally understand its strength. Especially the fact that its strength is distributed across its frontal defenses. We'll attack the front and keep our enemy occupied while the others by the east gate.

battle.speaker: Cornelia
battle.line: Titanus, my lovely dolls... Seek out the enemy and destroy them! And if the chance presents itself, I wouldn't mind being rid of those unsightly Kingdom forces too!

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: Are those Cornelia's magical weapons? Impressive.

battle.speaker: Felix
battle.line: Want to die? Step forward. I'll take you all.

battle.speaker: Ingrid
battle.line: We all chose our paths and I've chosen mine. I fight for my lord, to the death!

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: Traps awaiting us inside the castle... What a nuisance. But with such large-scale traps, there must be some sort of mechanism to control them.

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: The traps are still functional. There must be more of these devices.

boss.speaker: Rodrigue
boss.line: So this is it... Your Majesty... Please bring us victory!

boss.speaker: Felix
boss.line: Father... I will fight in your stead.

boss.speaker: Gwendal
boss.line: Does a whelp like you really expect to kill me? I am Gwendal, the Gray Lion, a knight by the hand of Count Rowe! Do your worst!

boss.speaker: Gwendal
boss.line: So this is where I meet my end...

boss.speaker: Cornelia
boss.line: Oh my, what a charming guest. Let me take care of you...

boss.speaker: Cornelia
boss.line: Gah! So this is as far as I could get...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: What turn of events has brought you so suddenly to Garreg Mach, Uncle?

end.speaker: Lord Arundel
end.line: Well, my business in the old Alliance territory had roughly finished. I wanted to see the face of my niece, who so bravely took Arianrhod. I have heard that it was done with truly magnificent tact. And that you even deceived some of your allies.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: I'm happy to have earned your praise. However, to say that I deceived my allies is a bit misleading. I despise leaks of information, and there may have been a church rat hiding amongst our ranks.

end.speaker: Lord Arundel
end.line: Ah, I see. However, there are some unfortunate consequences. Cornelia surely planned to betray them, but...she has been struck down. Truly wasteful meddling. Unless... Was it your intention to kill her?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: It was.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Professor, don't joke about that. The only ones we came to kill were our enemies.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: It was not.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I didn't care either way.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Indeed. We came only to kill our enemies.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: She used a terrible magic weapon... Dolls that she could move and fight with. Did you know about them?

end.speaker: Lord Arundel
end.line: Well now... If that were the case, would it not have been better to keep her as an ally? If you are only capable of such imprudence, this dark cloud might hang over the Empire's future as well.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Thank you for your concern. However, I will sweep aside any darkness that comes our way.

end.speaker: Lord Arundel
end.line: I will be praying. Praying that the Empire will not become another Arianrhod.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Another Arianrhod? Just what do you mean...

end.speaker: Lord Arundel
end.line: Hmph. I must take my leave now. Farewell.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Lady Edelgard, there you are. We just received some truly shocking news. It is said that pillars of light have rained from the heavens and disintegrated Arianrhod.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Disintegrated?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: How is that possible...

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: It was likely some type of magic... Perhaps a forbidden art.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Was it Lord Arundel...

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Why would he do that?

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Was Lord Arundel just here? So that would mean...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Hubert! Give me the full report!

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Ah, my apologies. I, of all people, should be able to control my discomposure. The pillars of light descended and exploded, resulting in the complete destruction of the main building and the north wall. It is believed that all key people within House Rowe, including its leader, were killed. Of the Imperial officers and men we kept at Arianrhod, about a third are unaccounted for...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: It can't be true... So...this is my uncle's trump card. In exchange for striking down Cornelia, he has destroyed Arianrhod!

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Perhaps we acted too soon in our disposal of Cornelia...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: No. If we'll be fighting them soon, there's no disadvantage to weakening their forces. It's also extremely valuable that we forced them to show their hand. Hubert, the investigation you made into the legend of Ailell, the Valley of Torment... This is likely what took place back then as well.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Yes... The probability is high.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Valley of Torment?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: The same thing happened in the past?

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Yes, it is quite likely.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: North of Garreg Mach there is a valley where the earth is always aflame. Once, javelins of light fell from the sky there... They pierced the earth and set the forest ablaze, creating a land of torment. We believed it may have been the work of the goddess, but... It was actually an attack by those who slither in the dark. That sums up all that we know.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: By giving us that knowledge, those who died at Arianrhod will not have died in vain.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: Indeed. It would be good to control the flow of this information.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: True. We'll conceal this from everyone as best as we can. I trust you, my teacher.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: I'm sure everyone has heard about what transpired at Arianrhod. The church has displayed their cowardice by indiscriminately using forbidden practices to kill the residents there. Their victims also include members of House Rowe, the Imperial army, and many, many more.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: According to our investigation, the forbidden attack that destroyed Arianrhod cannot be used again so quickly. Even so, we cannot delay our efforts. We must put a stop to all of this by the end of next month. The leader of one of the Imperial factions has already initiated an attack on the Fraldarius territory lost by Rodrigue... Soon, all obstacles blocking our path to Fhirdiad will have vanished.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: A cornered animal is at its most deadly. We must move quickly. Next, we march through the Tailtean Plains. After that, we destroy Fhirdiad. At that time, complete Imperial control over Fódlan will finally be a reality.

end.speaker: Caspar
end.line: Ah, I'm shaking with excitement! Bring on the battle!

end.speaker: Dorothea
end.line: I understand that a confrontation is inevitable. Still... I wonder if there's some path we could take that would cause less suffering...

end.speaker: Petra
end.line: This is the only path for the goal we are reaching for, and so we must keep walking on it. We are walking down the path to a better tomorrow.

end.speaker: Linhardt
end.line: A cornered church... Hmm, well, count me out from any forbidden sorcery that can destroy whole cities. If only there was an easier way to get more information on Crests and Relics...

end.speaker: Ferdinand
end.line: You are as negative as usual, Linhardt. We have but one order. To emerge victorious!

end.speaker: Bernadetta
end.line: We're going to win this! We really are! After all, if we lose, everything will be terrible forever! Oh, no way! We can't let that happen!

end.speaker: Caspar
end.line: There's a lot to worry about, but...I'm sure it will all work out! We'll win no matter what!
